Authors:
Valeria B Ponizovskaya, Alexey Grum-Grzhimaylo, Marina L.
Georgieva, Elena N. Bilanenko
Title:
Lecanicillium gracile (Cordycipitaceae), a new species
isolated from mineral building materials
Keywords:
biodeterioration, Lecanicillium, limestone, new species,
plaster, taxonomy
Abstract:
We report abundant lecanicillia fungi isolated from
deteriorated limestone and plaster in interiors of cultural heritage
sites in Russia. The phylogenetic analysis of ITS rDNA coupled with
morphological observations showed one of the Lecanicillium isolates as a
new species, which we describe here as L. gracile sp. nov. Lecanicillium
gracile is morphologically similar to the closely related species, such
as L. coprophilum, L. restrictum and L. testudineum, but it differs from
them by the ability to produce phialides secondarily on the preceeding
phialides. Additionally, L. gracile has a growth preference towards
higher temperatures, when compared to L. restrictum. Another abundant
Lecanicillium isolate we left unidentified due to a lack of phylogenetic
signal. A third species isolated from deteriorated limestone and plaster
in interiors was identified as Parengyodontium album, which is
phylogenetically close to Lecanicillium and produces zigzag-shaped tips
of conidiogenous cells. Given high abundance of the isolated species and
their physiological traits, we conclude that they are involved in
deterioration of stone materials in interiors of cultural heritage and
deserve attention during restoration works.
